ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to write clearly; how to write frequently & deal with writer's block; how to appreciate prose to a much deeper level

This course taught me so much about writing! We learn how to write short sentences. This is so important when it comes to all types of writing. I never thought I'd enjoy non-fiction creative writing, but The Genre of the Sentence completely changed that. Verlyn is the absolute best, and makes this course what it is: incredible.
I became a better, clearer writer!
How to write clear and effective prose, starting at the sentence level.
I became better at making simple sentences. Writing for rhythm. Paying attention to what interests me.
Improved ear for rhythm, syntactical snarls.

You learn quite simply how to write better from a sentence level. This means mostly technical work (words to avoid, structure, word choice, clarity). Towards the end of the semester you will work more thematically.

I thought I was a good writer  and, looking back, I wasnt bad  but this class really changed writing for me. I dont even know if its possible to explain exactly what I learned from this course, its not really a set of rules or principles or anything like that. A semester of writing every week and then getting in depth, personal feedback just really makes you internalize things. This class just made good writing so much easier.
clear, concise writing

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strength of the course lies in Verlyn's feedback and in what he teaches you about his thoughts on writing; weekly feedback is key!

Strengths: a wonderful classroom environment, reading peer work and learning from it, great and productive reading assigned, Verlyn's office hours, and discovering your voice within your own writing! 

Weaknesses: none.

Strengths  clear curriculum, manageable workload, clear growth
Weaknesses  no requirement to engage with classmates work
The team of Verlyn and Emily was a huge strength of this course. They were great resources independently and a great teaching duo. The weekly feedback was a huge strength of the class.

I met often with Verlyn and Emily in office hours. Their availability and insight was a great strength. The consistent structure of the class also worked well, especially at the beginning of the semester. The weekly assignment of writing two pages each week meant that we had a consistent form in which to experiment.

That being said, the course might be improved by some variation, especially later in the semester. I would have liked to spend a couple of weeks on revision. And it would have been nice to give us an opportunity to edit each others' pieces outside of class. Perhaps towards the end of the semester, we could have been split into pairs and asked to give comments on the other's piece before they submit it.

Strengths: well-organized, feedback each week, practice each week

Weaknesses: in-class experience is not as engaging as out of class work, the reading discussions feel a little like one-offs
strengths: weekly writing assignments and accompanying feedback, and Verlyn and Emily! they're truly wonderful; weakness: I wasn't a big fan of 90% of the assigned readings

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes!!!! If you feel a close connection to writing and wanting to make it more tangible, take this course. Don't be afraid of taking it as a STEM major, as well - I was perfectly fine amongst English majors.

Yes!!! Take this course. Verlyn is the absolute best. You'll learn how to write well. You'll read great writing, from published authors and your peers. You'll wonder how a two hour class can go by so quickly. And you'll wish you met more than one a week. This class will take you on a writing journey, and it is spectacular. There are hard days, days you're uninspired, days you feel stuck. There are also days where you have so many ideas, it's hard to choose just one. Where you want to share your writing with everyone you know because you are proud of it. Where you discover something in the process of writing. And those good days are so worth it. Take this class if you can (and go to office hours every week, it really helps)!!!
Yes!!!! No course has improved my writing so much.
Yes, this was the best class. You will not look at writing, your own nor others, the same way after this class. I could not recommend it more.
Definitely. It changed the way I write and read. It made me think about writing as more of an opportunity, less of a burden. I was introduced to some excellent writers, which is always a good thing.

Yes! It was such a pleasure taking Verlyn's class. He's a master at his craft and I really got to see my writing develop over the course of the semester. I love love this class. Take it if you have the chance.
If you haven't read the book.

Yes, if you are going to take the time to be engaged not just in your work but in the work of your classmates. I wish I would have taken more time to read my peers' pieces each week, because that would have helped the entire semester feel like it had progressed.
I think anyone that can take this class should take this class. Its not hard and yet it does so much more than any other writing class Ive ever taken.

extras.title: ENGL 474 01 - The Genre of the Sentence
